    Head W --

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head W be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1OO4*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs L. P. Rodrigo, Teong Eng Siong, P. Govindaswamy and Dr Ong Leong Boon.)

    Sir, the officials of the Ministry of Finance as guardians of public funds are expected to be meticulous in processing proposals for the financing of public projects. But in the

Column: 914

process, when the guardians of Government purse become an obstruction to development, then something is really, wrong. Let them process the proposals but let them not sit on them.

    When querying revotes for a number of items of Development Estimates in the various Ministries, I am told that among other things, some projects could not be proceeded with as a result of the difficulty posed by the Ministry of Finance in respect of releasing funds.

    Sir, when budgetary provisions are made for any financial year, before parliamentary approval is sought, the Budget Division of the Ministry of Finance would have screened the requirements of the various Ministries, queried the needs for such projects and having been satisfied, the provisions would then be tabled in Parliament. Since these provisions have been approved by the Ministry of Finance and consequently

Column: 915

approval has been obtained from Parliament, I fail to see the reason for a delay in releasing funds.

    Having made this general remark, can I now turn to a specific issue where there has been an unnecessary delay in releasing funds for the construction of a community centre in the Telok Blangah constituency? For FY 75, $10.8 million was approved as contribution to the People's Association which included provisions for building community centres. Having accepted a suitable site in Telok Blangah from the Housing and Development Board, the People's Association approached the Ministry of Finance for the release of funds in order to purchase the site on 29th September, 1975. Since then, six written reminders have been sent to the Ministry of Finance. A number of telephone calls requesting the Ministry to expedite processing have also been made. The latest written reminder was made on 22nd March, 1976. Six months have passed since the first request was made, and still the People's Association is awaiting release of funds which was approved by Parliament last year. Meanwhile, the MP for Telok Blangah is pressing the People's Association to process the plans and to submit the plans to the Planning Department. The Housing Board, on the other hand, is also pressing the People's Association for payment. Cost of building is going up and up and Telok Blangah is without a community centre.

    I concede that the Ministry of Finance should exercise sufficient checks and balances before releasing public funds but it should never become a bottle-neck for public development.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Budget speech which was delivered on 1St March 1 976 announced no tax increases except on cigarettes. This is indeed good tidings for the people. The increased tax on tobacco should not affect the general livelihood of the people except cigarette smokers. Therefore, for the sake of the health of the people especially the younger generation who should not be encouraged to smoke, I believe that such tax increase on a non-essential item will receive

Column: 916

the support of the majority of the people. What 1s amusing is that the Minister himself earnestly pleaded certain people including some of his Cabinet colleagues to give up smoking. I believe the Minister himself is not a smoker. Mr Speaker himself is also not a smoker because. I believe he is a doctor and he knows that smoking is bad for the health. Smokers tend to rationalise their bad habit by saying that a cigarette after a meal will induce a sense of euphoria. Men of letters say that smoking will help them to think better and will bring richer inspiration to them. So they go on smoking for the rest of their lives. Those who smoke, including Ministers, Parliamentary Secretaries and Backbenchers, should pay heed to what the Finance Minister has said and give up smoking in order to safeguard their physical and mental health so that they may not dissipate themselves away.

    Sir, I would like to raise four questions under this amendment. First, on economic growth, as the Minister for Finance has pointed out, last year was a bleak year of economic recession. The major industrialised countries, e.g., the United States, Japan and West Germany, were in the throes of depression resulting in a rapid decline in industrial production and mass unemployment. In spite of this adverse international economic recession, we were able to register a 4.1% economic growth which was not as good as in the year 1975 when the growth rate was 6.8%. However, this is still a very creditable performance compared with other developing countries. The fact that despite economic recession we were able to progress steadily and to carry out our various economic developments, could be attributed to three important factors. First, the farsightedness of the Government in carrying out various practical economic policies to promote industry and trade. Secondly, the enormous outlay on infrastructure in the public sector resulting in considerable success in anti-depression measures. Thirdly, our workers' diligence, and high level of technological skill contributing greatly to our economic development. Although the Minister has criticised our workers saying that they are not

Column: 917

as hardworking as those in Korea and Taiwan or Hong Kong, however, I am sure that by and large, our workers are hardworking and are not inferior to them. Now my question is: When the international economic situation has recovered from the recession, are we well prepared to catch up with such a recovery speedily? If so what are the prospects of our economic progress this year? Can the Minister forecast the growth rate for this year?

    The second question relates to the control of inflation, The rate of inflation is quickly declining and according to the consumers' price index there was only an increase of 3% last year. This has resulted in a definite improvement in the cost of living of the people generally. Compared with Japan, Hong Kong, and Taiwan our price index here is much lower than in those countries. In spite of this, the retail prices of certain food items are still very high, for example, the retail price of pork. Although the price of pigs has gone down to $110 or $120 per picul, the retail price of pork has so far remained unchanged. I would like the Minister and the Consumers' Association as well to take note of this. I believe the Government should do something to bring about a reduction in the price of food. Although the Consumers' Association of Singapore has done well in bringing about a lowering of prices, it must spare no effort to monitor food prices and make suggestions to the Government to maintain a fair level of prices in order to alleviate the burden and hardship of the people.

    The third matter is on how to encourage our people to use local products. The Economic Survey made by the Ministry of Finance says that about 57% of consumer goods were imported, while locally produced consumer goods constituted only about 43%. Obviously this is a problem that we should pay careful attention. On the one hand, while our products are very popular abroad, on the other hand our own people do not seem to be interested in our own local products. Thus, large sums of money will have to be spent on

Column: 918

foreign exchange to import foreign goods. Why should our people pay more for imported goods than buy our own local goods which are cheaper? I do not think the quality of our local products is inferior to the imported products because the popularity of our goods abroad is a clear evidence of the good quality of local products. What then is the reason? I feel that the reason is a psychological one and an improper understanding of the true quality of local products. Therefore, the first problem to tackle is to instil a confidence in our people in locally produced goods. In this respect, the Trade Department should get all the manufacturers and merchants concerned together to organise trade exhibitions jointly every year in order to introduce our local products and their good quality to the people and to foster their understanding and confidence in locally produced goods n order to buy more of them. Ideologically we should also encourage the patriotic consciousness of our people. This will not only help `the promotion of our local industries but also will be conducive to our economic development. I hope the Government department concerned would try to launch such campaigns on a large scale in order to promote the popularity of our locally produced goods and help their development.

2.45 p.m.

    Fourthly, the Minister for Finance also said that the Asian Dollar Market has achieved some progress last year. This could be seen from the increase of investment in our Asian Dollar Market last year, which totalled some USS 12.6 billion, or 22% more than 1974. From the point of view of our development as a financial centre, our Asian Dollar Market is successful. This achievement has given greater confidence in international circles and has induced them to make large capital investments in our financial market, and this also helps to strengthen our currency, The Minister has given three tax concessions to further develop our Asian Dollar Market. I would like the Minister to give more details of the activities of the Asian Dollar Market, and I would also like to suggest four proposals to the Minister.

    The Chairman: Mr Teong, your time is up.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, before I make my speech, I agree with the Member for Sembawang regarding his comments on smoking. But if he takes too much meat he will suffer a heart attack. Therefore he must be careful in not taking too much meat. While advising other people, he must also look after himself.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I notice that we have 2,414 vacancies in Division I alone, and so many Ministries are short of these officers. Is this caused by officers in the Government sector migrating to the private sector? Or is it due to their emigrating to other countries? May I ask what steps are being taken to reduce this migration of officers? I suggest that further incentives be introduced to retain them so that they will be able to produce work that will best suit their ability. Every Ministry has a shortage of staff, so much so that temporary recruits are being taken in. For how long are they going to be temporary? They themselves do not know. Why is the Finance Minister not taking steps to fill the gap instead of relying on the temporary staff who feel insecure and after some time would leave for greener pastures in the private sector.

    There was a hint recently that the automatic yearly wage increments would from now on be subject to productivity. This casts a pessimistic note on the 13th month allowance and the NWC recommendations for this year. May I know what is the position of the NWC recommendations? Could the Minister elaborate? I hope the NWC recommendations are not taken away, because the people's burden of livelihood has been cushioned by these allowances to meet the increased cost of living. But if this is withdrawn, it will affect the daily expenses of the ordinary worker. I wonder whether all the past recommendations will be consolidated in the pay chits. At the moment there are so many allowances stated in the pay-slips, such as NWC recommendations for 1973. 1974 and 1975, leave allowance, shift allowance, etc. These allowances are rather confusing, when it comes to analysing them. I wonder whether the Ministry will consider

Column: 920

consolidating these allowances without any loss to the wage earners.

    In the past many hotels have been built. Tourists were encouraged to come to Singapore. Now what has happened to the occupancy rate of hotels? There seems to be a downturn in the number of tourists coming to Singapore. Despite this the international airport at Changi is to be expanded. Can the Minister supply facts and figures on this matter and state whether any move is being made to raise the occupancy rate of our hotels?

    In the trading section, it seems that ships calling at Singapore are not as many as before. What has happened to our trading missions? How best have they been successful? Our statistics show that trade with Japan, America and European countries have gone down. Why is this so? Is the Government doing anything to revive our trade with these countries?

    Next, on Singapore Airlines, how are we faring in competition with the other airlines? What is our profit during the last one year and are we expanding the airlines?

    Sir, previously there was a tendency to house many offices and various departments under one roof. But, of late, owing to traffic congestion, the Government tends to decentralise some of the departments all over the island. Although this may be a good move to ease traffic congestion, there may be difficulty for a member of the public who has to go to several departments to settle a problem. He will have to travel from one area to another. I hope the Minister will see that the departments are not scattered in a way that will cause inconvenience to the public.

    On the subject of inflation, with the assistance of the various consumer associations we have been able to curb profiteering to a great extent. Though the prices of many commodities have gone down, we still find hawkers quoting exorbitant prices. What is the use of having price tags when no one is checking on the prices quoted? For instance, iced water costs 10 cents a glass. If you buy it in a plastic bag it costs 20 cents. Just imagine, one has to

Column: 921

pay the extra 10 cents for the bag alone. In all the hawker centres too you will find that the prices are high. The people have no choice but to pay for it. Will the Minister see that remedial steps are taken against unfair profiteering?

    Banks in Singapore open for business at 10 a.m. and close at 3 p.m. during weekdays and from 10 a.m. to 11.30 a.m. on Saturdays. These hours are extremely short, and the banks are still observing these times introduced during the colonial days, though the work-pattern and the number of working hours have changed. Banks, except the POSB, have not adjusted their hours of business as far as service to the public is concerned. It is time the banks were made to realise that it is for their own good and for the convenience of the public to extend the banking hours.

    Sir, the economic policy of 1976 seems to lay emphasis on the growth of the private sector. This emphasis is on diversifying productivity, increasing the skills of our workmen and to train them in higher levels of technology in skill intensive industries. This is a right move. It is this type of workman that Singapore needs badly.

    It is my hope that the private sector will introduce a better disciplined force of workers so that our productivity will increase several fold and benefit Singapore in return.

    Finally, I would like to comment about the ugly tendency that is growing in certain departments. Whenever a Member of Parliament requests certain matters on behalf of his constituents, a blunt "no" is given by some officials who quote rules and regulations to support their negative answers. However, the same officials are very lax towards other enquirers who do not go through the MPs, and they seem to get away with whatever they do. In some cases if an MP's request is turned down, the same person gets things worked out through other loopholes. Something is drastically wrong somewhere. Why do these loopholes exist, and why do these officials make use of these

Column: 922

loopholes to oblige certain individuals and to turn down others according to their whims and fancies? I hope the Minister will see that no double regulations are used in all Government departments.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, in this august chamber where the n-ale sex reigns supreme, it is with some trepidation that I seek to raise the subject of preferential treatment of the male sex in respect of medical benefits for Government officers, and I should hope my male colleagues will join me to seek redress for our fair ladies from the Hon. Finance Minister.

    Sir, medical attention is given to a Government officer and his family, at all Government hospitals and clinics. This health care is free for attendance at all outpatients clinics, though a nominal ward charge is imposed for in-patient treatment. This is the mainstay of the medical benefits entitlement for civil servants and other Government officers.

    However, as laid Out in IM No. 2 an officer means. and includes, an officer or pensioner of the Government of Singapore or a woman officer who is a widow or divorcee or who has been granted a decree of judicial separation and is the sole supporter of her family. The term "family" is defined as:

    (a) a wife and child (or children) in the case of a male officer, and

    (b) a child or children in the case of a woman officer who is a widow or divorcee or who has been granted a decree of judicial separation and who is the sole supporter of her family.

    Sir, what the above amounts to is that male officers enjoy medical benefits which are automatically extended to his wife and children, whereas female officers are entitled to such benefits only for herself. Her husband and children are not accorded free medical benefits, and they will have to pay.

    Only in exceptional circumstances, and these are very unhappy and unfortunate circumstances as I had qualified earlier, is the

Column: 923

child or children able to receive free health care.

    I cannot understand this unequal treatment of the female officers of the Government who, in almost every way are equal to men.

    They are employed like men to various jobs based essentially on merit. Only in certain situations such as hospitals and public cleansing work do we see an all-female or all-male cast. These situations are so because of different work demands, but facilitated by the traits inherent in the X or Y gene.

3.00 p.m.

    In keeping with the Government's philosophy and practice of equal treatment for both sexes, and our avowed distaste for sex discrimination, I shall be most grateful if the Hon. Minister for Finance could comment on the anomalous situation of less equal benefits for woman officers and to consider granting equal medical benefits to all officers, regardless of sex, lest we as a Government he labelled "practitioners of sex discrimination" or male chauvinists.

    An Hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to refer to the question of policy in regard to payroll tax. This subject has an interesting history. In December 1965 the then Minister for Labour, presently Minister for Culture, described the tax as one (at that time) foolishly imposed when we were in Malaysia. However, it was intended to continue collecting and to set aside the revenue to form a fund for the social security of workers. It was envisaged that a committee would be set up to put up recommendations for the implementation of the scheme.

    Five years later in 1970 the question of this payroll tax was again raised, by the Member for Kallang. The then Finance Minister replied that to-date (1970) a total revenue of $51 million had been collected. He added that the Government had set the question of unemployment insurance and had sought advice from ILO. An ILO expert's

Column: 924

view, it appeared, did not favour an unemployment benefits scheme and the Government decided to abandon for the time being the introduction of unemployment insurance based on payroll tax contributions. The Finance Minister stated that Government wanted to use payroll tax contributions to offset liabilities which employers incurred when they employed discharged national servicemen who were called up for their annual training exercises.

    The following year in 1971 the present Finance Minister announced that he had news which employers should welcome, namely, that the proceeds of the payroll tax would be used to compensate employers for the makeup pay when national servicemen are called up for annual training exercises and to allow reimbursements to industrialists for approved training or approved apprenticeship schemes.

    This is 1976 and we still have not got a clear idea of what we are going to do with the millions we have to-date collected, including the anticipated $57 million for this coming financial year. Could the Minister tell us what we have done specifically with the monies that we have collected, and how much has been spent for what? What is the philosophy behind the collection of this tax which actually works against the good employer who has to pay more because he pays his workers better? The idea of using the tax for incentives to develop skills is a good one because, on balance, it may be found that the inculcation of skills would make for better returns than just stashing the money away and finding as the years pass by that money value has been eroded. I think a clear explanation of policy on this subject would be advantageous. At the same time, the Minister would surely know that the Auditor-General has reported that, from a statistical sampling for the period January to June 1973, it was discovered that there was a rate of evasion of payment of this tax ranging from 5.5% to 8.8% Perhaps the Minister could care to comment on this also.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I refer to the Minister for Finance's observation on wages policy in his

Column: 925

Budget statement on 1st March, 1976. He said:

    'The time has come for the National Wages Council to consider whether it should not include all forms of wage increases, including annual increments, incentive, allowances and bonuses, in the computation of the annual NWC wage supplement to arrive at a single total annual increase.'

    I would like to make reference, Mr Speaker, Sir, to the recent statement that "for Singapore workers the days of automatic increases were over." Since this statement is obviously linked with the Minister's observation it would seem, therefore, that the Minister for Finance is suggesting that we do away with annual increments for workers on the grounds that the annual increments will by augmenting the NWC wage-hike upset the national economic equilibrium.

    Sir, I respectfully submit that any attempt to abolish wage scales would be a retrograde step. Annual increments for workers must be viewed against the background of their introduction for the lower income group. If we disregard the rationale behind annual wage increments, we will be doing so at our own peril. It must be remembered that, generally speaking, annual increments of wages for workers are comparatively new in origin because, briefly, wage scales bring about a sense of security for the workers.

    Let me outline the history. In the not so recent past when the extreme left wing elements dominated the labour movement their tactic was not to have wage scales but short-term contracts with employers so that at regular intervals they could confront management with new and unreasonable wage increases so as to bring about industrial unrest. This also gave the left-wing trade union leaders a firm hold over the rank and file, because if the workers had not backed them up in creating labour unrest which could even wreck our economy they were put at the mercy of the unenlightened employer and doomed to no wage increases whatsoever. It was to remove this sense of insecurity which was often the source of labour unrest that wage scales were

Column: 926

introduced. Thus being assured of his rice bowl the worker could devote all his efforts and energy on his work and productivity without the nagging fear that he may be Out on a limbo when the union's collective agreement with the management expires.

    Sir, if we do away with salary scales and annual increments, we might well bring back the old scenario and once again have a restive labour force, all waiting with agony and fear as to what would happen on expiry of their collective agreements.

    In regard to the NWC's recommendation for wage increases, it must be pointed out that this was a measure introduced to meet a new phenomenon that of a rising cost of living a phenomenon which has made its greatest impact in post-war years. Those of us who belong to the older generation and who were working before the war will remember that even after the Great Depression the term "inflation" was hardly ever heard of in this part of the world nor did it cause any social or economic problems. It was only after 1939 with the outbreak of war in Europe was there any appreciable rise in the cost of living for government to take cognisance of the matter.

    In the first few years after the end of World War II there was not really any marked upsurge in prices and in the cost of living. It was only in the last few years, in the wake of rapid industrialisation and full employment, did rising prices and the cost of living make such an impact that it has necessitated state intervention to provide remedial act on to contain rising prices since external factors and the unrestricted free enterprise could otherwise upset not only our people's livelihood but also our very economy.

    Sir, the recommendation of the National Wages Council must be seen in this context to meet higher prices and the rising cost of living. The wage supplement recommended by the National Wages Council is thus the extra quantum of money that has to be made available to the employee to augment his remuneration so as to redress the imbalance between his actual monetary remuneration and the purchasing power of his wages.

Column: 927



    The inflation that we have experienced during the past few years is not the making of the workers of Singapore but imported inflation due to external factors which are beyond the control of the workers. In the circumstances, it will be unfair to blame the worker for expecting a wage supplement to enable him to meet rising prices. The wage supplement of the National Wages Council can therefore be viewed as a stop-gap measure. Wage increases are only recommended when the situation warrants it. If our statistics show that there is no fall in the purchasing power of the dollar, there will undoubtedly be no wage supplement recommended by the National Wages Council.

    In this context. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is clear that the National Wages Council's wage supplement is thus only an adjustment to meet the rising cost of living. If, therefore, the Government envisages difficult times ahead and a slowdown in our economic growth, I have no doubt that the situation will be reflected in the National Wages Council's recommendation. But this does not mean that the annual increments provided in the worker's wage scale should be abolished. It must not be forgotten that wage scales were obtained after hard bargaining on the part of the unions, very often at times when we were fighting the communists, and to suggest that they should be scrapped on the ground that wage increases should from now on only hinge on improved effort and output is most illogical and could even be construed as a breach of faith. One does not chase the rat by burning the house down.

    Encik Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir. just now the Member for Katong pointed out that I raised the question of payroll tax a few years ago. I am going to raise it once again.

    I propose, for the consideration of the Minister for Finance, that payroll tax collected should be designated and expended for the purpose of approved courses in industrial joint training centres conducted by the private sector and courses conducted by the Industrial Training Board, the National Productivity Board and the Adult Education

Column: 928

Board. I consider it quite appropriate that the tax which has been imposed on employers, based on their payroll, should benefit both the employers and the employees. Consideration might also be given to exempt employers from paying payroll tax if their annual expenditure for their own courses designed to upgrade the skills exceeds the payroll tax they are liable to pay.

    Payroll tax is levied under the Finance Act (Payroll Tax) (Cap. 139) at the rate of 2% on the total payroll of a trade, business, profession or vocation carried on in Singapore. Payroll tax collected for 1975 was roughly $49 million. For 1976, payroll tax to be collected is an estimated sum of $57 million. The total amount of payroll tax collected from February 1965 to February 1976 was $263 million. If this tax is utilised for the purpose I have proposed, it should give the incentive for employers to devise and to conduct suitable training schemes.

3.15 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance in his Budget statement has urged the workers to upgrade their skills and the employers to improve their personnel management for the sake of improving productivity. The workers at large are normally blamed for any high cost in wages or payroll. This tax is no exception. This tax has not been used for the general good of the workers. How much opportunity and time are given to the large number of workers to improve their skills when they are limited to doing routine work? Let us create a climate where the people, like the Germans, for example, are incessantly seeking knowledge and wanting to improve their skills. In this connection, I think the Adult Education Board and such like agencies should now get out of their normal way in creating interests amongst our adult population in furthering their education. I do not believe the Minister for Finance will agree with me after he had formulated his Budget and presented it to Parliament. However, who knows, he might!

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, I did propound the need for a Small Claims Court during the debate on the

Column: 929

Budget statement. This needs to be elaborated on at the present juncture.

    Time and time again, complaints by dissatisfied consumers against retailers find difficulty in obtaining redress because of the small nature of the claims. Either consumers feel that it is not worth it to go to all the trouble to litigate or find litigation too costly. However, justified complaints like these, if accumulated, could mean consumers losing large sums of money and guilty retailers getting away with trade malpractices and ill-gotten gains, much to the detriment of their honest counterparts.

    The formation of a Small Claims Court could act as a deterrent to undesirable trade malpractices. Court fees would not be too costly and judgment in favour of a party would include recovery of fees. The most that can he claimed could be in the region of sums less than $500.
